oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Buddy Killen Interview Side One - Tree International
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Bob Allen interviewing Buddy Killen of Tree International. The recording takes place on 8-31-79.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Buddy Killen
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:51) -- Bob Allen asks Buddy Killen about artist payments. (1:11) -- Bob Allen asks Buddy Killen about the tapes pitched to him daily. Buddy Killen describes the process of finding new acts. (2:14) -- Bob Allen asks Buddy Killen how many acts he is currently producing - Louise Mandrell, Joe Tex, T.G. Sheppard, Audrey Landers. (3:23) -- Buddy Killen describes that he is currently producing for 10 different acts. (4:09) -- Buddy Killen describes working 18-20 hours a day from January-July. He would stay in the studio almost the entire night when producing. (6:12) -- Buddy Killen clarifies that everything he works on goes through Tree Publishing production company, despite working with other labels. (7:25) -- Bob Allen asks about the "energy" present at Tree Publishing Company. "Jack [Stapp] and I both have always wanted to be a part of what's going on." - Buddy Killen. (9:02) -- Buddy Killen discusses the history of his personal drive to succeed. (10:16) -- Buddy Killen describes a story about bouncing a ball against a wall in his first small office with Tree on 17th Avenue. (12:52) -- Bob Allen compares Tree Publishing Company to other publishing companies in Nashville. (14:20) -- "You can't stop and rest on your laurels, you'll get cold." - Buddy Killen. (14:48) -- Buddy Killen describes his presidential roles at the company (Tree). (15:54) -- Buddy Killen describes the song "Golden Ring" by Bobby Braddock. (17:06) -- Bob Allen asks about the early days of Tree Publishing Company. (18:42) -- Buddy Killen describes finding "Heartbreak Hotel." (20:32) -- Bob Allen asks about young writers dominating the charts, particularly the ones at Tree Publishing Company. (21:27) -- "We've always had an open mind about songwriting." - Buddy Killen. (22:02) -- Buddy Killen describes his ability to spot new artists' talent. Mentions Dolly Parton, Mel Tillis. (23:43) -- "By listening to all the bad songs that come in, you don't learn what a hit is, but you learn what a hit isn't." - Buddy Killen (25:05) -- Buddy Killen discusses the growth of Roger Miller & Bill Anderson. (27:43) -- Bob Allen asks if anyone has ever calculated the exact number of songs in the Tree catalog. (30:15) -- Bob Allen asks about artists statements. Buddy Killen discusses hits like "Green, Green Grass Of Home," "King Of The Road," "Funny How Time Slips Away." (33:09) -- Buddy Killen describes how producers are closing doors on minor publishing companies. Often times producers would call Tree for songs because of their reputation. (34:35) -- Bob Allen asks how much a #1 record for Kenny Rogers could make for a writer. (37:44) -- Bob Allen asks Buddy Killen about the challenge of keeping up with the enormous Tree catalog. (40:24) -- Bob Allen asks Buddy Killen about the overseas market for publishing. (41:26) -- "Music is an international language." - Buddy Killen (42:15) -- Bob Allen asks about Tree Publishing signing with EMI. (43:19) -- Buddy Killen discusses the purchase of the Pamper catalog. (45:47) -- Bob Allen asks Buddy Killen what his personal goals for Tree Publishing are going forward.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Killen, Buddy;
